de.uni.bamberg.wiai.minf.forflow.datagenerator.view.util
Class Splitter

java.lang.Object
  de.uni.bamberg.wiai.minf.forflow.datagenerator.view.util.Splitter

public final class Splitter
extends java.lang.Object

Splitter class is used to separate the path from the file name. It is needed to store the current working directory temporarily to get back in an instant. That means, if you're doing I/O operations, it's helpful to start in that directory where you left. This class helps to achieve that goal.

The constructor of this class is private, so you have no change to get an instance of it. But you should call the method provided directly, 'cos it is declared as static.

Since:
Apr/07/09
Version:
0.1
Author:
Michael Munz

Method Detail

splitPathAndFileName

public static final java.net.URI splitPathAndFileName(java.net.URI uri)
separates the path and the file name. The path is given as an URI reference object.

Example
Some examples of URIs are:
  • Web
    • http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.6/index.html
  • Windows
    • file:/C:/j2se/1.6/index.html
  • UNIX
    • file:/usr/j2se/1.6/index.html

Parameters:
uri - Represents a Uniform Resource Identifier reference.
Returns:
the path

  • Windows
    • C:/j2se/1.6
  • UNIX
    • /user/j2se/1.6

splitPathAndfileName

public static final java.lang.String splitPathAndfileName(java.net.URI uri)
separates the path and the file name. The path is given as an URI reference object.

Example
Some examples of URIs are:
  • Web
    • http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.6/index.html
  • Windows
    • file:/C:/j2se/1.6/index.html
  • UNIX
    • file:/usr/j2se/1.6/index.html

Assumption
This method is based on an assumption made because the file name is not always clear. Assume the file name is something like Course and it is an ordinary text file. On Windows the full file name would be Course.txt. Here's the file name is identified with the help of the file extension.

But what about UNIX systems. On UNIX the same file Course would be look like Course if serialized. There's no such thing like an file extension. And we cannot guarantee Course isn't a directory, when this method is called. We assume it and it it up to the user jumping to the right conclusions, because we haven't got the context.

Parameters:
uri - a path in the local file system
Returns:
the file name

getFileName

public static final java.lang.String getFileName(java.lang.String file)
gets only the file name and cuts off the file extension. There is a check, if the file has an extension and then the process of cutting is started.

Parameters:
file - a file name with extension
Returns:
only file name or null

getFileExtension

public static final java.lang.String getFileExtension(java.net.URI file)
gets the file extension of any file. It checks first if the file has got a file extension. If true, then the extension will be returned. Otherwise null is the returned result.

Parameters:
file - any file to which the extension is needed
Returns:
file extension or null

hasFileExtension

public static final boolean hasFileExtension(java.net.URI file)
checks whether the passed file, as an URI object, has any file extension. Usually this is an important question when a file is serialized. If the user typed in an valid (from the system supported) extension we wouldn't have done this again.

Parameters:
file - the file to check.
Returns:
true if and only if a file extension has been found
